attributes.title: Lab2Field experiment on the effects of framing and conflict on bureaucratic responsiveness

q1.value: Lab2Field experiment on the effects of framing and conflict on bureaucratic responsiveness

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: It is unclear whether when bureaucrats respond to citizens in an unequal manner, whether that is in line with what political principals want. Counter to agency theory, empirical evidence on party and politician behaviour shows that political principals choose to benefit certain citizen groups over others (Ezrow et al. 2010; Brookman & Butler 2015; Bojar 2017). Further, what citizens want might be influenced by what politicians want (Brookman & Butler 2015) It is easy to imagine that in a regime which does not conform to egalitarian principles of democratic representation, a bureaucrat responding to the needs and preferences of citizens, although their political principles demand differently, the bureaucrat would increase democratic accountability. On the other hand, if political principles enforce bureaucratic behaviour in such a manner that it conforms to democratic ideals, then such rogue behaviour would likely decrease democratic accountability. Given that the presentation of information can alter responses, this study aims to test: (1) whether bureaucrats respond to the stated needs and preferences of citizens, when political principles support such action; (2) whether bureaucrats respond to the stated needs and preferences of citizens, when political principles do not such action; and (3) whether this pattern changes when information about the stated needs and preferences of citizens is presented in a different manner. There are a myriad of ways how citizen information could be presented. This study will focus on two ways of presenting information: one mimics the results of a citizen survey, the other uses emotional words. While bureaucrats are often confronted with the former when they receive the results of citizen engagement efforts that use quantitative methods, they are likely to receive the latter when qualitative methods were employed or when they talk to citizens directly (e.g. as part of town hall consultation process, outreach activities or casual interactions with citizens).

q16.value: H1 When the feedback of political principals and citizens align, more bureaucrats will respond to the demands of citizens than when feedback is conflicting. In other words, we expect the average treatment effect of aligned feedback to lead to greater responsiveness towards the citizen than under conflict. Y is the relative willingness to implement changes that the citizen versus the politician proposed, and is the preferred choice of one proposal over other proposed changes. For simplicity, we only refer to in the following discussion. Models for will be detailed in the analysis section. In cases where they conflict, it is hypothesised that bureaucrats will yield more to politicians as they have greater power over their budgets, careers and other aspects important to their well-being. However, building on findings from behavioural science, it is expected that the effects will be attenuated or enhanced depending on the form in which citizen information is presented. H2 When the information is presented using emotional words compared to using unemotional descriptors, bureaucrats will be more responsive to citizens, in both the H2a consensus; and the H2b conflict scenarios; H2c and across scenarios.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested using a between-within survey experiment. Participants are randomised into one of two groups (between randomisation): they either receive information from citizens in (i) a “unemotional” manner, which mimics the way information is collated in large, representative surveys, or (ii) they receive the same information but featuring emotional words (“happy” and “sad”).

registration_responses.q1: Lab2Field experiment on the effects of framing and conflict on bureaucratic responsiveness
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

attributes.title: The Importance of Retributive Justice under Uncertainty using the World Values Survey

q1.value: The Importance of Retributive Justice under Uncertainty using the World Values Survey

q2.value: Paige Bollen | Lily Tsai | Jon Mellon | Tiago Peixoto | Johannes Hemker

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Under what conditions are individuals more likely to value retributive justice? Combining a large-scale survey experiment that tests the causal effect of priming individuals to think about agencies that punish government officials that misuse government funds on their attitudes toward taxation with novel machine learning techniques, we evaluate the moderating effect of social and economic uncertainty on the strength of the retributive justice prime. Specifically, we use advanced quantitative methods to explore variation in the strength of the retributive justice treatment effect, training causal forests to parametrically estimate features of the conditional average treatment effects across a battery of country-level characteristics.

q16.value: We hypothesize that economic and/or social uncertainty is associated with larger treatment effects for the retributive justice treatment. Specifically, we argue that economic and social uncertainty makes people more likely to value government as a provider of moral and social order and punishment that upholds order. People in contexts with relatively higher uncertainty are thus more likely to express willingness to pay taxes when reminded about the strength of top-down channels for anti-corruption. Specifically, we have two primary hypotheses: 1) Individuals in countries with relatively higher levels of economic uncertainty are more likely to have higher estimated conditional average treatment effects; and 2) Individuals in countries with relatively higher levels of social uncertainty are more likely to have higher estimated conditional average treatment effects. Our independent and dependent variables come from the original tax morale survey (already described in another Pre-Analysis Plan). We combine these data with country-level data from a variety of sources, relying primarily on data from the World Bank, the World Values Survey (Inglehart et al., 2014), and the Quality of Governance dataset (Teorell et al., 2019). The survey data collected a limited amount of individual-level data, so our analysis primarily focuses on exploring heterogeneity across country-level covariates that capture economic uncertainty, social uncertainty, and other country-level characteristics that are common controls, but unrelated to uncertainty.

q17.value: We test our hypotheses about heterogeneous treatment effects as a result of uncertainty using two recent machine learning approaches. We start by implementing a nonparametric causal forest to estimate which variables are the most important for predicting heterogeneous treatment effects (Wager and Athey, 2018). We measure variable importance by looking at the reported by the grf package (Athey and Wager, 2018) “variable importance” score for each covariate included in the causal forest. The variable importance measure reported by the grf package is based upon a count of the proportion of splits on the variable of interest, weighting these proportions by the depth of the tree where the split occurs, with partitions occurring at lower depths receiving a lower weight. We predict that variables related to economic and social uncertainty will have higher variable importance scores. We then cross-validate this approach by using the recent method outlined by Chernozhukov et al. (2018), which focuses on using the random forest algorithm (Friedman et al., 2009) consisting of a large number of Classificaiton and Regression Trees (CART) (Breiman et al., 1984) to estimate features of the Conditional Average Treatment Effect (CATE) rather than the CATE itself because it relaxes many of the required assumptions. We focus specifically on estimating the individual-specific conditional average treatment effects, grouping those individuals into quintiles based on their predicted conditional average treatment effect, and then taking the difference in means of the included covariates between those in the highest and lowest quintile of predicted conditional average treatment effects. Under our hypotheses, we would expect the difference in means of covariates that are associated with social and economic uncertainty to be statistically significant from zero between those in the highest and lowest quintiles.

attributes.title: Do Women Make More Credible Threats? Gender Stereotypes, Audience Costs, and Crisis Bargaining

q1.value: Do Women Make More Credible Threats? Gender Stereotypes, Audience Costs, and Crisis Bargaining

q2.value: Joshua A. Schwartz | Christopher W. Blair

q5.value: Generous Support for this research is provided by the Time-Sharing Experiments for the Social Sciences and the Christopher H. Browne Center for International Politics.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: During the 1984 presidential campaign, Geraldine Ferraro, the first major-party female vice-presidential candidate in US history, was asked at a debate, “...do you think in any way that the Soviets might be tempted to try to take advantage of you simply because you are a woman?” (Ferraro and Franke 2004: 40). This statement reveal a pervasive gender stereotype: that men are better equipped to handle national security issues than women (Rosenwasser and Dean 1989; Kahn 1992, 1994; Alexander and Anderson 1993; Huddy and Terkildsen 1993; Sanbonmatsu 2002; Lawless 2004; Dolan 2004, 2014; Falk and Kenski 2006; Holman, Merolla, and Zechmeister 2011). While gender stereotypes persist, the number of female political leaders has grown starkly over time. The growing prevalence of women in high political office thus raises important questions about the role of leaders’ gender in the conduct of war and peace. Toward this end, we investigate how common gender stereotypes affect crisis bargaining dynamics. Specifically, we address a gap in the literature by presenting the first evidence of how gender stereotypes affect leaders’ abilities to generate audience costs. The timing of this study is auspicious. Given that a historic number of women are running for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2020, it is imperative to understand how common gender stereotypes affect foreign policy decision-making and interstate conflict.

q16.value: First, we hypothesize that female US presidents facing male foreign leaders, female US presidents facing female foreign leaders, and male US presidents facing female foreign leaders will pay greater inconsistency costs and lower belligerence costs compared to male US presidents facing male foreign leaders. Second, we posit that that aforementioned effects will be stronger among older and more sexist respondents. Third, we hypothesize that Democrats and individuals low in militant assertiveness will punish leaders more for belligerence, while Republicans and individuals high in militant assertiveness will punish leaders more for inconsistency.

q17.value: To test our theory, we conduct a between-subjects survey experiment whose design closely follows that of seminal audience costs experiments conducted by Tomz (2007) and Kertzer and Brutger (2016). However, in contrast to these past experiments, we experimentally manipulate the gender of the US president and the foreign leader.

q19.value: About 1700, though the exact number may change depending on the number of subjects made available to us by TESS.

q27.value: Time-Sharing Experiments for the Social Sciences (TESS)

attributes.title: For Club or Country? Using Football Data to Test Theories of Group Identity

q1.value: For Club or Country? Using Football Data to Test Theories of Group Identity

q5.value: We thank Jay Van Bavel and Shanker Shanker Satyanath for helpful comments on the design. We thank the team at Football Addicts, including Patrik Arnesson, Gustaf Rasmusson, Johanna Garå, Kalle Ringberg and Kristofer Melin for a very fruitful collaboration

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Social identity theory suggests that an individual's sense of "who they are" is based in part on their group memberships. These group memberships importantly raise self esteem by conferring a sense of pride or belonging but also cause individuals to categorize members and nonmembers of these groups ("us" versus "them"). A large body of social science research has demonstrated the effects of group identities on behaviors ranging from cooperation to ethnic conflict. Many football supporters consider themselves to be part of the professional clubs they support and derive some of their sense of who they are from their connection to these clubs. In addition, football supporters, like all individuals, identify to some extent with their home nation. Social identity theory suggests that both these identities (club and country) help determine the players they cheer for in league and international competitions. We are collaborating with a football fan app, Forza Football, to conduct this study. The Forza Player of the Season (POS) competition, conducted each May, provides an excellent opportunity to test the degree to which these group identities influence individuals' behavior. POS candidates have (at least) two important components to their identity: their nationality and the professional club they play for. Social identity theory predicts that Forza users should have a stronger connection to players that share their club identity compared to players who do not. The same logic holds for national identity. The basic idea of our experiment is simple: we randomly add one of these identities---club or nation---below the name displayed in the app for the POS candidates. That is, below Lionel Messi's name, users will either see "FC Barcelona," "Argentina" or nothing. The purpose of this is to make a particular component of the player's identity salient, thus prompting Forza users to consider whether they share that identity before casting their vote. Our expectation is that sharing the identity made salient by the prompt increases a player's support among Forza voters compared to a baseline where no identity information is provided. In addition, not sharing that identity reduces a player's support.

q16.value: Our basic research question is "Do individuals change their behavior, in this case their POS vote, when one attribute of a candidate's identity (club or national) is made more salient?" Our expectations are the following: 1. Compared to the baseline condition, the national condition will lead to more support among co-nationals; 2. Compared to the baseline condition, the national condition will lead to more support among strong national identity co-nationals; 3. Compared to the baseline condition, the national condition will lead to less support among those with strong antipathy towards the nation; 4. Compared to the baseline condition, the club condition will lead to less support among co-nationals; 5. The national condition will result in higher support among co-nationals than the club condition 6. Compared to the baseline condition, the club condition will lead to more support among co-supp orters; 7. Compared to the baseline condition, the club condition will lead to more support among strong club identity co-supp orters; 8. Compared to the baseline condition, the club condition will lead to less support among those with strong antipathy towards the club; 9. Compared to the baseline condition, the national condition will lead to less support among co-supp orters; 10. The club condition will result in higher support among co-supp orters than the national condition

q17.value: We will simply compare mean rates of voting across treatment conditions.

q18.value: Egypt, UAE, Denmark, Netherlands, Great Britain, United States, Ireland, South Africa, Australia, Nigeria, Ghana, Kenya, India, Canada, France, Belgium, Switzerland, Cameroon, Germany, Austria, Greece, Italy, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Brazil, Russia, Spain, Mexico, Argentina, Chile, Colombia, Sweden, Turkey

attributes.title: The Effects of Arguments for Gender Quotas: A Survey Experiment on Representatives in Norway.

q1.value: The Effects of Arguments for Gender Quotas: A Survey Experiment on Representatives in Norway.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The aim of this study is to learn more about preferences of elected representatives for the implementation of gender quotas. In particular, we are interested in the effects of different types of positive arguments on preferences, and whether these preferences vary when they are proposed to take place in different domains (religion/business/politics).

q16.value: We expect that arguments in favour of gender quotas will also lead to a higher likelihood of supporting gender quotas; that this is particularly so in the fields of business and religion; that arguments revolving around talent are the most powerful; and that ideology/gender/the perception of gender inequality as a problem/perceptions of immigrants condition these effects

q17.value: We conducted a survey experiment and included several questions in a survey among elected representatives in Norway. We analyse the results with OLS.

q23.value: It has been reviewed and approved on the basis of ethics by the Scientific Committee of the Panel of Elected Representatives (PER)

attributes.title: A Way Out? Apprenticeship Training, Employment and Social Transformation in Northern Nigeria

q1.value: A Way Out? Apprenticeship Training, Employment and Social Transformation in Northern Nigeria

q2.value: Benjamin Crost | Oeindrila Dube | Marcus Holmlund | Eric Mvukiyehe

q5.value: Many thanks to Adam Smith International (Mafita Project Team) and DFID for making this work possible. Funding from DFID Nigeria is gratefully acknowledged. Also, thanks to the DIME team in DC and Nigeria for their invaluable inputs in making this study possible.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The UK Department for International Development (DFID) has funded the Mafita Program which delivers skills training interventions, implemented by Adam Smith International, that aim to improve the economic opportunities of marginalized youth in Northern Nigeria. Since the late 1970s, Northern Nigeria has been the site of religious and ethnic conflicts that have led to substantial violence and instability. These conflicts are thought to be fueled by the region’s high rates of poverty and unemployment, as well as its large population of marginalized urban youth. Particularly notable in this context are the Almajirai, children of poor families from rural areas who migrate to cities to study in Qur’anic Schools. Observers of the region worry that, due to their lack of economic opportunities, these youths become easy targets for recruitment by violent groups and criminal organizations. This study will evaluate the impact of an apprenticeship intervention delivered by the Mafita program to over 3,000 young men and women. The program is unique in targeting highly marginalized individuals, including many Almajirai. The intervention first delivered 6 months of foundational training in basic literacy, numeracy, project funding, working in teams, and managing relationships. It then linked participants to Master Craft Persons (MCPs) with whom they completed 6-9 months of apprenticeship. The apprenticeship intervention recruited participants in Kano state. The program recruited from six categories of persons in the pilot period: Almajirai boys, Adolescent Girls in Islamic and Quranic Education (IQE), Persons with Disabilities (PWDs), Orphans and Vulnerable Children (OVC), and Early School Leavers (ESL). Recruitment was based on two primary selection criteria: (i) being in the age bracket 15 to 24 years old, and (ii) living on less than N225.76 (about $0.65 in today’s exchange rate) per day.

q16.value: The proposed impact evaluation seeks to answer three research questions. 1. Can the apprenticeship training intervention delivered by the Mafita program increase the labor-market outcomes and economic well-being of marginalized youth? 2. Does this intervention induce changes in religious, social and political attitudes, and alter youth tendencies to engage in criminal and violent activities? 3. What—if any—heterogeneous impacts does the intervention produce? Our primary hypothesis is that the Mafita program will have positive effects on the primary and secondary outcomes listed below. The study will estimate the effect of the apprenticeship intervention on a set of 7 primary and 9 secondary outcomes. Primary outcomes 1. Income generating activities (in past 30 days) 2. Participation in political and religious violence. 3. Attitudes toward religious adherence and religious enforcement 4. Female empowerment 5. Caregiver female empowerment 6. Anti-social behavior 7. Generosity toward other religions: donation experiment Secondary outcomes 8. Attitudes towards political violence 9. Religious social network (for the purpose of this outcome, a respondent’s social network is defined as the five people he/she spends the most time with) 10. Religiosity 11. Subjective well-being 12. Self-esteem 13. Skills 14. Assets and consumption 15. Job search behavior 16. Range of social networks (for the purpose of this outcome, a respondent’s social network is defined as the five people he/she spends the most time with)

q17.value: For the directly measured outcomes (all outcomes except Outcome 7: Generosity toward other religions: donation experiment.) we will combine all survey responses related to an outcome into a mean effects index, following Kling et al. (2007). To do this, we will first express responses in terms of standard deviations from the control group mean. We will then sum all standardized responses related to an outcome into an index switching signs if necessary to ensure that the positive direction always indicates a “better” outcome. We will also report a robustness test using the method of Anderson (2008), which weights the index items by their inverse covariance matrix. We will also present estimates of individual indicators within each family to better gauge how various indicators contribute to overall effects within families. For certain outcomes, we will test the primary hypothesis only for the subsample of male or female respondents. Specifically, we will test the primary hypothesis for outcomes 2 and only for the subsample of male participants and we will test the primary hypothesis for outcome 4 for the subsample of female respondents. As part of the heterogeneity analysis, we will also report estimates for outcomes 2 and 6 for women and outcome 4 for men. For outcome 7, which is measured by a choice experiment, we will use the estimation procedure. This is described in section 4.4 of the PAP that is attached. For each primary outcome, we will estimate one regression using the mean effects index as the dependent variable and adjust p-values for multiple comparisons by controlling the False Discovery Rate (FDR) using the step-up procedure proposed by Benjamini, Krieger and Yekutieli (2006). When examining individual indicators within outcomes we will control the FDR across indicators within the outcome.

q19.value: The pool of youth applicants comprised 5,165 individuals, 3,066 of whom were randomly assigned into the treatment group while the remaining 2,099 were assigned to the control group. The endline survey also covers 3,070 unique caregivers.

q24.value: National Health Research Ethics Committee of Nigeria (NHREC); NHREC Protocol Number NHREC/01/01/2007-19/10/2018; NHREC Approval Number NHREC/01/01/2007-11/11/2018

registration_responses.q1: A Way Out? Apprenticeship Training, Employment and Social Transformation in Northern Nigeria
registration_responses.q2: Benjamin Crost | Oeindrila Dube | Marcus Holmlund | Eric Mvukiyehe
registration_responses.q5: Many thanks to Adam Smith International (Mafita Project Team) and DFID for making this work possible. Funding from DFID Nigeria is gratefully acknowledged. Also, thanks to the DIME team in DC and Nigeria for their invaluable inputs in making this study possible.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: The UK Department for International Development (DFID) has funded the Mafita Program which delivers skills training interventions, implemented by Adam Smith International, that aim to improve the economic opportunities of marginalized youth in Northern Nigeria. Since the late 1970s, Northern Nigeria has been the site of religious and ethnic conflicts that have led to substantial violence and instability. These conflicts are thought to be fueled by the region’s high rates of poverty and unemployment, as well as its large population of marginalized urban youth. Particularly notable in this context are the Almajirai, children of poor families from rural areas who migrate to cities to study in Qur’anic Schools. Observers of the region worry that, due to their lack of economic opportunities, these youths become easy targets for recruitment by violent groups and criminal organizations. This study will evaluate the impact of an apprenticeship intervention delivered by the Mafita program to over 3,000 young men and women. The program is unique in targeting highly marginalized individuals, including many Almajirai. The intervention first delivered 6 months of foundational training in basic literacy, numeracy, project funding, working in teams, and managing relationships. It then linked participants to Master Craft Persons (MCPs) with whom they completed 6-9 months of apprenticeship. The apprenticeship intervention recruited participants in Kano state. The program recruited from six categories of persons in the pilot period: Almajirai boys, Adolescent Girls in Islamic and Quranic Education (IQE), Persons with Disabilities (PWDs), Orphans and Vulnerable Children (OVC), and Early School Leavers (ESL). Recruitment was based on two primary selection criteria: (i) being in the age bracket 15 to 24 years old, and (ii) living on less than N225.76 (about $0.65 in today’s exchange rate) per day.
registration_responses.q16: The proposed impact evaluation seeks to answer three research questions. 1. Can the apprenticeship training intervention delivered by the Mafita program increase the labor-market outcomes and economic well-being of marginalized youth? 2. Does this intervention induce changes in religious, social and political attitudes, and alter youth tendencies to engage in criminal and violent activities? 3. What—if any—heterogeneous impacts does the intervention produce? Our primary hypothesis is that the Mafita program will have positive effects on the primary and secondary outcomes listed below. The study will estimate the effect of the apprenticeship intervention on a set of 7 primary and 9 secondary outcomes. Primary outcomes 1. Income generating activities (in past 30 days) 2. Participation in political and religious violence. 3. Attitudes toward religious adherence and religious enforcement 4. Female empowerment 5. Caregiver female empowerment 6. Anti-social behavior 7. Generosity toward other religions: donation experiment Secondary outcomes 8. Attitudes towards political violence 9. Religious social network (for the purpose of this outcome, a respondent’s social network is defined as the five people he/she spends the most time with) 10. Religiosity 11. Subjective well-being 12. Self-esteem 13. Skills 14. Assets and consumption 15. Job search behavior 16. Range of social networks (for the purpose of this outcome, a respondent’s social network is defined as the five people he/she spends the most time with)
registration_responses.q17: For the directly measured outcomes (all outcomes except Outcome 7: Generosity toward other religions: donation experiment.) we will combine all survey responses related to an outcome into a mean effects index, following Kling et al. (2007). To do this, we will first express responses in terms of standard deviations from the control group mean. We will then sum all standardized responses related to an outcome into an index switching signs if necessary to ensure that the positive direction always indicates a “better” outcome. We will also report a robustness test using the method of Anderson (2008), which weights the index items by their inverse covariance matrix. We will also present estimates of individual indicators within each family to better gauge how various indicators contribute to overall effects within families. For certain outcomes, we will test the primary hypothesis only for the subsample of male or female respondents. Specifically, we will test the primary hypothesis for outcomes 2 and only for the subsample of male participants and we will test the primary hypothesis for outcome 4 for the subsample of female respondents. As part of the heterogeneity analysis, we will also report estimates for outcomes 2 and 6 for women and outcome 4 for men. For outcome 7, which is measured by a choice experiment, we will use the estimation procedure. This is described in section 4.4 of the PAP that is attached. For each primary outcome, we will estimate one regression using the mean effects index as the dependent variable and adjust p-values for multiple comparisons by controlling the False Discovery Rate (FDR) using the step-up procedure proposed by Benjamini, Krieger and Yekutieli (2006). When examining individual indicators within outcomes we will control the FDR across indicators within the outcome.

attributes.title: Salient Events and Theories of Power

q1.value: Salient Events and Theories of Power

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: How does political change happen? Anyone who wants to influence politics must answer this question. There are two main hypotheses which are, at times and in different contexts, more or less correct. The elite "republican" theory of change is that the way to influence politics is to persuade, cajole, and motivate those with power. The mass "democratic" theory of change is that the way to influence politics is to organize people to engage in collective action. These theories then lend themselves to different strategies: "lobbying" the elite or "mobilizing" masses. The question then becomes: where do these theories come from? This experiment tests one hypothesis: exposure to salient examples regarding the success of a strategy will impact the willingness of individuals to engage in lobbying or mobilizing behavior. Subjects are randomly exposed to excerpts of real news reports on the political activities of the National Rifle Association (NRA). One story describes the success of the NRA as due to its financial lobbying activities. The second story describes the success of the NRA as due to its mobilization of collective action by its members. I propose that those who are exposed to the a mobilization (lobbying) narrative are more (less) likely to (1) have higher external efficacy (belief that average citizens can influence politics), (2) are more likely to report "mass mobilization" strategies as influential, and (3) are more likely to report a willingness to participate in mass mobilization. Furthermore, I argue that lobbying narratives increase willingness to engage in "out of system" forms of participation, as the system itself loses credibility. In a political environment in which the influence of "special interests" is a salient narrative on both sides of the aisle, I argue the omnipresence of this narrative actually makes that narrative truer.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1a: Manipulation check Exposure to a mobilization narrative will increase the belief that the NRA's success is due to recruitment of members. Hypothesis 1b: Manipulation check Exposure to a lobbying narrative will increase the belief that the NRA's success is due to raising money. Hypothesis 2a: External Efficacy Exposure to a mobilization narrative will increase the belief that citizens can influence politics compared to both a pure control and a lobbying narrative. Hypothesis 2b: External Efficacy Exposure to a lobbying narrative will decrease the belief that citizens can influence politics compared to both a pure control and a mass mobilization narrative. Hypothesis 3a: Strategies Exposure to a mobilization narrative will increase the belief that mass mobilization strategies can influence politics compared to both a pure control and a lobbying narrative. Hypothesis 3b: Strategies Exposure to a lobbying narrative will decrease the belief that mass mobilization strategies can influence compared to both a pure control and a mass mobilization narrative. Hypothesis 4a: Actions Exposure to a mobilization narrative will increase willingness to take part in mass mobilization strategies can influence politics compared to both a pure control and a lobbying narrative. Hypothesis 4b: Actions Exposure to a lobbying narrative will decrease willingness to take part in mass mobilization strategies compared to both a pure control and a mass mobilization narrative. Hypothesis 5: Within and Out of System Exposure to the lobbying narrative will decrease (increase) belief in the effectiveness and the willingness to take part in "within system" (out of system) forms of participation. (This is a secondary hypothesis and not theoretically tied to the others)

q17.value: • Manipulation check: "What do you think is more responsible for the political success of the National Rifle Association?" o Those who receive the mobilization prime should say members. Those who receive the lobbing prime should say money. • Do you agree with this statement: "People like me don't have any say about what the government does." o Those who receive the mobilization prime should agree less. Those who receive the lobbing prime should agree more. • How effective do you think each of the following political acts are at influencing political outcomes? o Those who receive the mobilization prime are expected to think all acts are more effective EXCEPT donating to a candidate or cause. o Those who receive the lobbying prime are expected to think joining a violent event is more effective. • This will be strongest for Democrats. • How likely are you to do each of the following political acts in the next two years? o Those who receive the mobilization prime are expected to be more willing to do all acts EXCEPT donating to a candidate or cause. o Those who receive the lobbying prime are expected to be more willing to join a violent event is more effective. • This will be strongest for Democrats.

attributes.title: Reintegration of Rebel Collaborators: Survey Experiments in Mosul

q1.value: Reintegration of Rebel Collaborators: Survey Experiments in Mosul

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: What are the conditions under which civilians will accept neighbors who collaborated with a rebel group back into their community after conflict? What are the effects of different accountability mechanisms on reconciliation and social cohesion in post-conflict settings? How does variation in the identity of a rebel "collaborator" (e.g. gender, age, or co-ethnicity) and the type of collaboration (e.g. marriage, combat, or employment in a civilian job such as a cook or janitor) affect the prospects for his or her reintegration into a post-conflict society? Mosul, an Iraqi city that was recaptured by Iraqi forces in 2017 after more than three years of control and governance by the Islamic State (IS) is an ideal site in which to seek answers to these questions, which are crucial to the stabilization and reconstruction of war-torn societies around the world. The return and reintegration of thousands of IDPs to areas recaptured from IS raises important questions for communities that have been divided between supporters and opponents of IS. Will these returnees be able to trust and coexist peacefully with those who stayed in IS-controlled Mosul and cooperated with the group to varying extents? Does willingness to forgive rebel collaborators depend on the nature of the punishment he or she has received (ranging from more lenient and restorative punishments such as community service to harsher ones such as imprisonment)? Through two embedded experiments in an original survey of 1,400 residents of Mosul, we will identify the effects of hypothetical collaborators' identity and the type of collaboration on respondents’ preferences for punishment, forgiveness, and reintegration.

q27.value: Independent Institute for Administration and Civil Society Studies (IIACSS)

attributes.title: The Presidenta Effect: Perceptions of Women in Politics in Post-impeachment Brazil

q1.value: The Presidenta Effect: Perceptions of Women in Politics in Post-impeachment Brazil

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: About five years ago, scholars frequently pointed to the elections of Michelle Bachelet in Chile, Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner in Argentina, and Dilma Rousseff in Brazil, as a sign that, in Latin America, traditional biases against women in politics were eroding. In the period since, various events have suggested that the demonstration effects of these female presidents may have not been entirely positive; and that they may even have worked to negatively impact the ways in which voters evaluate women’s performance and place in politics. If true, Latin America’s female presidents may have had the opposite effect on symbolic representation to the one anticipated by literature. Yet, the potential negative consequences of female presidents’ political failures remain uncharted territory. Rousseff’s recent impeachment in August 2016 provides an ideal scenario with which to investigate the strength of demonstration effects of an embattled female president on women’s symbolic representation. The question emerges: how did Dilma Rousseff’s impeachment impact the future prospects for female politicians in Brazil? To answer this question, we employ two separate online surveys, one from a convenience sample (N=1,173), and another from a nationally-representative sample (N=1,500). The first study has at its core goal establishing Brazilian voters’ baseline evaluations of female and male politicians in post-impeachment Brazil. To understand whether voters’ assessment of Rousseff translates into broader views about women in the political sphere, we employ a second online survey which combines experimental techniques with an Implicit Association Test (IAT) and more traditional survey questions.

q16.value: H1: On average, voters are more likely to associate political attributes with male politicians, but that they are particularly more likely to associate negative political attributes with men. H2a: On average, being primed to consider the repercussions of Dilma Rousseff’s presidency and impeachment weakens voters’ association of negative political attributes with men in political office. H2b: The effect of this priming is stronger among male voters than female voters. H3: On average, being primed to consider the repercussions of Dilma Rousseff’s impeachment should have no effect of voters’ explicit evaluations about women’s fit for office. H4: On average, being primed to consider the repercussions of Dilma Rousseff’s impeachment negatively impacts female voters’ self-evaluations of their qualifications for running for office, as well as their reported intentions to do so. H5: On average, reflecting on their potential implicit biases towards men and women in politics, leads voters to reinforce these biases in their explicit (but private) associations of women’s appropriateness for political office. H6: On average, the estimated implicit associations of participants will be better predicted by their political ideology than by their measured implicit associations.

q17.value: H1) H1 will be tested using non-experimental survey data collected with a convenience sample of Brazilian voters (N=1,173). Essentially, the objective of this exercise is to establish a baseline for voters’ assessments of female/male politicians in Brazil. In the survey, participants were asked to select six positive and six negative attributes of politicians they found to be the most desirable and undesirable, respectively, and then to assess the extent to which each of these terms were masculine or feminine. For each of the twenty-five words in each list, we then code binary variables in which 0 signifies that a respondent did not select the word, and 1 signifies that a respondent selected the word. This variable is used to assess the frequency in which each term was selected, thus allowing us to identify the most important positive and negative attributes according to voters. We assess voters’ top preferences by calculating frequency distributions for each word for the entire sample of respondents; to verify the robustness of these preferences, we also conduct sub-group analyses across sex (male/female); race (white/non-white); age (44 and under/45 and older); income (up to 2 minimum wages/more than 2 minimum wages); partisanship (PT partisans/non-partisans and Dilma voters/non-Dilma voters); and, regions (North, Northeast, Center-West, Southeast, South). We then assess the extent to which voters characterize top positive and negative attributes as feminine or masculine using the variables attributeX_gendered , which capture individuals’ assessment of each word they selected and for which: -2 refers to “very masculine,” -1 to “somewhat masculine,” 0 to “neither masculine or feminine,” 1 to “somewhat feminine,” and 2 to “very feminine.” We conducted this analysis as before: by calculating the mean values of each variable for the entire sample of respondents; to verify the robustness of these preferences, we also conduct sub-group analyses across sex (male/female); race (white/non-white); age (44 and under/45 and older); income (up to 2 minimum wages/more than 2 minimum wages); partisanship (PT partisans/non-partisans and Dilma voters/non-Dilma voters); and, regions (North, Northeast, Center-West, Southeast, South). H2) H2-H5b will be tested using experimental survey data collected with a nationally-representative sample of Brazilian voters (N=1,500). H2a and H2b will be tested by conducting T-tests of the differences in means of respondents’ D-scores, by treatment and control groups. As per Greenwald et al. (2003), D-scores are calculated using respondents’ scores on blocks 3, 4, 6, and 7 of the IAT and capture respondents’ implicit associations in respect to women’s fitness for office. D-scores can be calculated in three different ways, depending on the set-up of the IAT. We use the default D-score calculation provided by IATgen. D-scores have a possible range of -2 to 2, with positive values pertaining to a positive bias pertaining to women’s fit for office, and a score of 0 referring to no gender-based bias. Because we are interested in average effects across treatment and control groups, but also anticipate heterogeneous effects across gender and partisan lines, we also conduct T-tests by treatment and control groups among sub-groups of participants. Namely, female/male; PT partisans/non-partisans; Dilma voters/non-Dilma voters. As additional tests, we also conduct T-tests of average reaction times for male political positions and average reaction times for female political positions. This means that we take the male political position average reaction time from the T-test output for female participants, and the male political position average reaction time for male participants. This is done as a means of further assessing the degree of masculinity assigned to positive or negative attributes. H3) H3 will be tested by conducting T-tests of the differences in means of respondents’ answers to explicit questions pertaining to women’s fit for office (as specified below), by treatment and control groups. To confirm that null effects persist, we assess potential heterogeneous effects across gender and partisan lines. As such, we also conduct T-tests by treatment and control groups among sub-groups of participants. Namely, female/male; PT partisans/non-partisans; Dilma voters/non-Dilma voters. Have you ever voted for Dilma for President, or another woman for President or any other office? (Please mark all that apply). Yes, I voted for Dilma Rousseff for President (1) I voted for another woman for President (1) I voted for a woman for Governor (1) I voted for a woman for Mayor (1) I voted for a woman for Senator (1) I voted for a woman for Federal Deputy (1) I voted for a woman for State Deputy (1) I voted for a woman for Municipal Deputy (1) No, I have never voted for a woman (0) No, I have never voted or would vote for a woman (-1) • Scores to this question correspondents to summative value of all positive answers, thus possibly ranging from -1 to 8. To what extend do you agree with the statement: “Dilma Rousseff’s impeachment is evidence that women IN GENERAL are less competent politicians than men”. 0 = Completely agree. 1 = Somewhat agree. 2 = Somewhat disagree. 3 = Completely disagree. H4) H4 will be tested by conducting T-tests of the differences in means of respondents’ answers to questions about their self-evaluations to run for office (as specified below), by treatment and control groups. As per the literature on symbolic representation, we only derive expectations for the ways in which the treatment might impact women (but not men). As such, we anticipate heterogeneous effects across gender, thus conducting T-tests by treatment and control groups among female respondents. How would you classify your qualifications to occupy elected office? 0 = Extremely unqualified 1 = Somewhat unqualified 2 = Somewhat qualified 3 = Extremely qualified How likely are you to run for office? 0 = Extremely unlikely 1 = Somewhat unlikely 3 = Somewhat likely 4 = Extremely likely H5) H5 a and b will be tested by assessing the difference in aggregate means of respondents’ answers to the list experiment before and after being debriefed about the purpose of the IAT (see questions below). As per the set-up of list experiments, individual-level analyses are not possible, only being possible to assess the ways in which exposure to the debrief impacted before and after aggregate outcomes. This means that respondents’ individual answers to the debrief question are not taken into account in the analysis of list experiments. List experiment 1: The experiences encapsulated in the statements below sometimes make people upset or uncomfortable. After reading all four statements, select HOW MANY of them upset you (not which ones, just how many). Young people making graffiti on the streets Political parties electing more female than male candidates (sensitive item) Students not having access to books People cutting line at the bank because of conditions of priority (e.g., age, pregnancy) IAT debrief: Almost everyone unconsciously makes associations based on gender stereotypes. This makes people perceive men or women as more skilled in a given area. The timed activity in the previous section measured the way you unconsciously rate the performance of men and women in politics. If you had to guess, how do you think was your rating in this activity? In other words, would you say that you unconsciously prefer men or women to exercise political office? To answer the question, complete the following statement with one of the options below: “I think that, unconsciously, I make…” -3 = Strong association between men and one’s capacity to occupy political office. -2 = Moderate association between men and one’s capacity to occupy political office. -1 = Slight association between men and one’s capacity to occupy political office. 0 = No association between sex and one’s capacity to occupy political office. 1 = Slight association between women and one’s capacity to occupy political office. 2 = Moderate association between men and one’s capacity to occupy political office. 3 = Strong association between men and one’s capacity to occupy political office. List experiment 2: The experiences encapsulated in the statements below sometimes make people upset or uncomfortable. After reading all four statements, select HOW MANY of them upset you (not which ones, just how many). Men driving in fast and dangerous manner Companies nominating only men to positions of leadership Women being elected to govern your state and municipality (sensitive item) Women crying to get what they want

H4: On average, being primed to consider the repercussions of Dilma Rousseff’s impeachment negatively impacts female voters’ self-evaluations of their qualifications for running for office, as well as their reported intentions to do so. H5: On average, reflecting on their potential implicit biases towards men and women in politics, leads voters to reinforce these biases in their explicit (but private) associations of women’s appropriateness for political office. H6: On average, the estimated implicit associations of participants will be better predicted by their political ideology than by their measured implicit associations.
registration_responses.q17: H1) H1 will be tested using non-experimental survey data collected with a convenience sample of Brazilian voters (N=1,173). Essentially, the objective of this exercise is to establish a baseline for voters’ assessments of female/male politicians in Brazil. In the survey, participants were asked to select six positive and six negative attributes of politicians they found to be the most desirable and undesirable, respectively, and then to assess the extent to which each of these terms were masculine or feminine. For each of the twenty-five words in each list, we then code binary variables in which 0 signifies that a respondent did not select the word, and 1 signifies that a respondent selected the word. This variable is used to assess the frequency in which each term was selected, thus allowing us to identify the most important positive and negative attributes according to voters. We assess voters’ top preferences by calculating frequency distributions for each word for the entire sample of respondents; to verify the robustness of these preferences, we also conduct sub-group analyses across sex (male/female); race (white/non-white); age (44 and under/45 and older); income (up to 2 minimum wages/more than 2 minimum wages); partisanship (PT partisans/non-partisans and Dilma voters/non-Dilma voters); and, regions (North, Northeast, Center-West, Southeast, South). We then assess the extent to which voters characterize top positive and negative attributes as feminine or masculine using the variables attributeX_gendered , which capture individuals’ assessment of each word they selected and for which: -2 refers to “very masculine,” -1 to “somewhat masculine,” 0 to “neither masculine or feminine,” 1 to “somewhat feminine,” and 2 to “very feminine.” We conducted this analysis as before: by calculating the mean values of each variable for the entire sample of respondents; to verify the robustness of these preferences, we also conduct sub-group analyses across sex (male/female); race (white/non-white); age (44 and under/45 and older); income (up to 2 minimum wages/more than 2 minimum wages); partisanship (PT partisans/non-partisans and Dilma voters/non-Dilma voters); and, regions (North, Northeast, Center-West, Southeast, South). H2) H2-H5b will be tested using experimental survey data collected with a nationally-representative sample of Brazilian voters (N=1,500). H2a and H2b will be tested by conducting T-tests of the differences in means of respondents’ D-scores, by treatment and control groups. As per Greenwald et al. (2003), D-scores are calculated using respondents’ scores on blocks 3, 4, 6, and 7 of the IAT and capture respondents’ implicit associations in respect to women’s fitness for office. D-scores can be calculated in three different ways, depending on the set-up of the IAT. We use the default D-score calculation provided by IATgen. D-scores have a possible range of -2 to 2, with positive values pertaining to a positive bias pertaining to women’s fit for office, and a score of 0 referring to no gender-based bias. Because we are interested in average effects across treatment and control groups, but also anticipate heterogeneous effects across gender and partisan lines, we also conduct T-tests by treatment and control groups among sub-groups of participants. Namely, female/male; PT partisans/non-partisans; Dilma voters/non-Dilma voters. As additional tests, we also conduct T-tests of average reaction times for male political positions and average reaction times for female political positions. This means that we take the male political position average reaction time from the T-test output for female participants, and the male political position average reaction time for male participants. This is done as a means of further assessing the degree of masculinity assigned to positive or negative attributes. H3) H3 will be tested by conducting T-tests of the differences in means of respondents’ answers to explicit questions pertaining to women’s fit for office (as specified below), by treatment and control groups. To confirm that null effects persist, we assess potential heterogeneous effects across gender and partisan lines. As such, we also conduct T-tests by treatment and control groups among sub-groups of participants. Namely, female/male; PT partisans/non-partisans; Dilma voters/non-Dilma voters. Have you ever voted for Dilma for President, or another woman for President or any other office? (Please mark all that apply). Yes, I voted for Dilma Rousseff for President (1) I voted for another woman for President (1) I voted for a woman for Governor (1) I voted for a woman for Mayor (1) I voted for a woman for Senator (1) I voted for a woman for Federal Deputy (1) I voted for a woman for State Deputy (1) I voted for a woman for Municipal Deputy (1) No, I have never voted for a woman (0) No, I have never voted or would vote for a woman (-1) • Scores to this question correspondents to summative value of all positive answers, thus possibly ranging from -1 to 8. To what extend do you agree with the statement: “Dilma Rousseff’s impeachment is evidence that women IN GENERAL are less competent politicians than men”. 0 = Completely agree. 1 = Somewhat agree. 2 = Somewhat disagree. 3 = Completely disagree. H4) H4 will be tested by conducting T-tests of the differences in means of respondents’ answers to questions about their self-evaluations to run for office (as specified below), by treatment and control groups. As per the literature on symbolic representation, we only derive expectations for the ways in which the treatment might impact women (but not men). As such, we anticipate heterogeneous effects across gender, thus conducting T-tests by treatment and control groups among female respondents. How would you classify your qualifications to occupy elected office? 0 = Extremely unqualified 1 = Somewhat unqualified 2 = Somewhat qualified 3 = Extremely qualified How likely are you to run for office? 0 = Extremely unlikely 1 = Somewhat unlikely 3 = Somewhat likely 4 = Extremely likely H5) H5 a and b will be tested by assessing the difference in aggregate means of respondents’ answers to the list experiment before and after being debriefed about the purpose of the IAT (see questions below). As per the set-up of list experiments, individual-level analyses are not possible, only being possible to assess the ways in which exposure to the debrief impacted before and after aggregate outcomes. This means that respondents’ individual answers to the debrief question are not taken into account in the analysis of list experiments. List experiment 1: The experiences encapsulated in the statements below sometimes make people upset or uncomfortable. After reading all four statements, select HOW MANY of them upset you (not which ones, just how many). Young people making graffiti on the streets Political parties electing more female than male candidates (sensitive item) Students not having access to books People cutting line at the bank because of conditions of priority (e.g., age, pregnancy) IAT debrief: Almost everyone unconsciously makes associations based on gender stereotypes. This makes people perceive men or women as more skilled in a given area. The timed activity in the previous section measured the way you unconsciously rate the performance of men and women in politics. If you had to guess, how do you think was your rating in this activity? In other words, would you say that you unconsciously prefer men or women to exercise political office? To answer the question, complete the following statement with one of the options below: “I think that, unconsciously, I make…” -3 = Strong association between men and one’s capacity to occupy political office. -2 = Moderate association between men and one’s capacity to occupy political office. -1 = Slight association between men and one’s capacity to occupy political office. 0 = No association between sex and one’s capacity to occupy political office. 1 = Slight association between women and one’s capacity to occupy political office. 2 = Moderate association between men and one’s capacity to occupy political office. 3 = Strong association between men and one’s capacity to occupy political office. List experiment 2: The experiences encapsulated in the statements below sometimes make people upset or uncomfortable. After reading all four statements, select HOW MANY of them upset you (not which ones, just how many). Men driving in fast and dangerous manner Companies nominating only men to positions of leadership Women being elected to govern your state and municipality (sensitive item) Women crying to get what they want
